questions.question_text:
Your company makes use of Platform as a Service (PaaS) for their Azure solution.
Which of the following options are components that Microsoft are responsible for? (Choose all that apply).

discussion.content: I hate these vaguely worded questions. If the question had said "Data" then that is the user's responsibility. Database can imply the structure that the data is kept in which would be the cloud providers responsibility or it can imply the data itself.
ABD are the answers

comments.content: On second thought, A and D are the answers; databases contain data which the customer is responsible for
That would mean if the SQL (or other database) server fails the customer is responsible ABD is correct
Text from provided URL: "PaaS includes...database management systems" ABD is correct.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABD
Simple

Selected Answer: ABD
In PaaS, the customer is generally responsible for the application and managing the data (e.g., structure and content), but not for the underlying infrastructure or database maintenance. In many cases, the cloud provider takes care of the database platform maintenance itself.

Selected Answer: ABD
Paas included all execpt application

Selected Answer: AD
A&D for sure. B, possibly. Storage is included both in infrastructure as a service and platform as a service. Operating system is not included in infrastructure as a service, but is in platform as a service. Platform as a service includes database management tools, but not the data to go in the database which is supplied by the customer. It is designed for application development so the customer is also responsible for the applications. Weather database is part of this question depends on whether database means the database tools, or the database itself.

Selected Answer: ABD
ABD are the answers
Everything except Data and Applications (in general)
Operating Systems & Storage

Selected Answer: ABD
A,B & D are the answers
A,B & D are the answers

Selected Answer: ABD
answer is abd

Selected Answer: ABD
Answer is A,B and D.
The PaaS provider hosts everything—servers, networks, storage, operating system software, databases, development tools—at their data center

Selected Answer: ABD
A, B and D.
IaaS then I think MS responsibility is devices, OS and maintenance. For example VM, CPU/GPU, Disk space, OS, etc. = In general "hardware" is MS responsibility I think.
Why should your Cloud service provider be responsible for your Databases ant their endurance and internal workings? I dont think so.

You manage the applications and services you develop, and the cloud service provider typically manages everything else.

Refer here:
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/overview/what-is-paas/
ABD - corretos
it is correct as on PaaS you are suppose to be bother of Application/domain - as PaaS is a development platform ( rest all is taken care by MS, like installing IIS etc)

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Share Point and Teams are SaaS
Answer is right
Correct. The No's are SaaS
similar on 4/23/24 exam.

- "Azure Virtual Machine é uma solução de Infraestrutura como Serviço (IaaS)": Sim (Sim)
- "SharePoint Online é uma solução IaaS": Não (Não). O SharePoint Online é uma solução de Software como Serviço (SaaS).
- "Microsoft Teams é uma solução IaaS": Não (Não). O Microsoft Teams também é uma solução de Software como Serviço (SaaS).

SIM - "Uma Máquina Virtual do Azure é uma solução de Infraestrutura como Serviço (IaaS)." NÃO - "SharePoint Online é uma solução de Infraestrutura como Serviço (IaaS)." NÃO - "Microsoft Teams é uma solução de Infraestrutura como Serviço (IaaS)".
I had this question in the exam today, the answers are right
IaaS/SaaS/SaaS
all are no because Azure is PaaS

comments.content: actually cancel that im wrong Azure VM is an IaaS solution
Except it does...? By using IaaS. you are responsible for managing the OS.
OS does not come under Iaas
Microsoft is wrong with their documentation. Another wrongly worded question

How can you even debate it? Microsoft has it stated in their own documentation.
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/resources/cloud-computing-dictionary/what-is-iaas

discussion.content: NO! yes, yes is the correct answer. OS does NOT fall under IaaS

Think about this....
Fact: VMs host an OS (e.g. Win10, Linux, etc). 
Fact: VMs are considered part of IaaS solution
Fact: Technically IaaS is providing an OS via the VM for the customer....same concepts applies to a SERVER which also hosts an OS (e.g. Win Svr 2019)....all of these OS's make the connections to storage and networking as well. 

With that rationale, the answer to: "Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) provides SERVERS, VIRTUAL MACHINES (VMs), storage, networks, and OPERATING SYSTEMS to customers"....the answer would be YES based on how the statement is worded and the facts that are known.

The trick to these questions is to not get caught up or look way deeper into the question beyond what it is asking. In a lot of these questions, there is a buzz word added that makes the answer more of a NO. That applies to all of these questions in MS-900 or for that matter, all questions on MS exams. MS purposely words these questions to try to get you to think beyond what they are asking. Try not to get wrapped around the axle.

comments.content: Thats correct. You buy your VM and can pay extra to have whatever version of Windows/Linux you want installed. There is also Azure Hybrid Benefit which is a licensing benefit that helps you to significantly reduce the costs of running your workloads in the cloud. It works by letting you use your on-premises Software Assurance-enabled Windows Server and SQL Server licences on Azure. And now, this benefit applies to RedHat and SUSE Linux subscriptions too

discussion.content:
NYY

OS is IaaS if you manage the Operating system
OS is PaaS if the vendor manage/provides the operating system

https://azure.microsoft.com/en-ca/resources/cloud-computing-dictionary/what-is-iaas
All Yes OS is Iaas
i belive instead of OS we need to focus on Servers as server is provided by cloud host not IAAS
frist statement is true!iaas provide server os and everything

- "Infraestrutura como Serviço (IaaS) fornece servidores, máquinas virtuais, armazenamento, redes e sistemas operacionais para os clientes": não
- "Plataforma como Serviço (PaaS) fornece um ambiente para construir, testar e implantar aplicativos de software": Sim (Yes)
- "Software como Serviço (SaaS) fornece um ambiente que é centralmente hospedado e gerenciado para os clientes": Sim (Yes)

discussion.content: exam Question in September
Y/Y/Y - again https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/security/fundamentals/shared-responsibility#division-of-responsibility
NO, Yes Yes.
Correct! OS does not fall under IaaS

comments.content: For everyone thinking OS falls under IaaS check the link dat jim85 posted.

discussion.content:
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/resources/cloud-computing-dictionary/what-is-iaas/

IaaS lets you bypass the cost and complexity of buying and managing physical servers and datacenter infrastructure. Each resource is offered as a separate service component, and you only pay for a particular resource for as long as you need it. A cloud computing service provider like Azure manages the infrastructure, while you purchase, install, configure, and manage your own software—including operating systems, middleware, and applications.

NYY correct
NO, Yes Yes. First is NO because per the link storage/network/security is not IaaS BUT OS is absolutely IaaS
Please stop upvoting anyone who says IaaS is not OS management. That is ludicrously incorrect and a key differentiator.
IaaS is where you can deploy your own choice of operating systems to run on. If the cloud service gives you OS then it is a PaaS.

Iaas do not have operating systems

Correct answers should No,Yes,Yes

N, Y, Y 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/security/fundamentals/shared-responsibility

these IaaS, PaaS, SaaS questions are quite annoying really as the borderline ones are , well a bit pointless in the real world anyway - like who cares about the label applied to it if you understand what it does!
BUT the key to this one is 'As A Service' part in IaaS - ask yourself what elements are being provided as a SERVICE , i.e. being provided by Microsoft and they are fully responsible for that part and you can remove OS from that making the first one NO.
Yes , an OS get included with the VM when you spin it up or it cant boot, but the OS is not managed by MS and therefore is NOT a service within IaaS.
using Iaas the user is responsible for the OS
It's a tough one because, you are provided the options of an OS with however it's your decision to use and mange it. But, it isnt part of the scope of IaaS so i think: no, yes, yes is what id go for
Can someone explain the SaaS 3rd option? The description sounds like it's IAAS to me
For certain Y/Y/Y is the right column.

the answer is correct 
No--> os not included in Iass

YES YES YESSSS

No Yes Yes; OS is PaaS
Just take Microsoft's word for it for they classify

OS is not classed under IAAS according to the Microsoft diagram on this link here. https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/overview/what-is-iaas/. Even looking at AWS IAAS, you get the console, IAM, FW Security groups, monitoring, you need to choose the OS or appliance. You just have to go with what is right in your learnings.
Correct answer: No, Yes and No.

OS is not part of the IaaS "package". Customers have to install an OS themselves and patch, maintain regularly as opposed to PaaS which comes with an OS and customers just have to worry about their applications and not OS

It should be No, Yes, Yes.

The Microsot says that " A cloud computing service provider, such as Azure, manages the infrastructure, while you purchase, install, configure and manage your own software – operating systems, middleware and applications."

comments.content: yeah strange that, I don't remember the last time I had to install a PaaS in a cloud provider, just configure and partially manage it.

discussion.content: Yes, Yes, Yes. Operating System falls under IaaS. Not PaaS.
NO YES YES

At a glance, Virtual Machines (VMs) consist of infrastructure to deploy an application. Specifically, this includes a persistent OS disk, possibly some persistent data disks, and internal/external networking glue to hold it all together.

https://azure.microsoft.com/en-au/blog/infrastructure-as-a-service-series-virtual-machines-and-windows/

see option number 1 is vague in regards to OS. But on a VM Microsoft and AWS both provide a stand version of OS and you don't need to purchase an OS. But maintaining or upgrading the OS is the responsibility of the end-user. So Iwill go with Yes-Yes-Yes
Correct No, Yes, Yes
I'll agree to the answer on the premises that Microsoft "provides" an operating system for their customers.

comments.content: OS are not IaaS. Not according to https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/overview/what-is-iaas/

OS are also IaaS. When you create an Azure VM, you still can pick an OS to go with it (server 2019, Windows 10, etc). You are responsible for keeping it patched, but OS's are part of IaaS in this use. PaaS includes fully managed OS environments where the OS is maintained by Microsoft
Yes, i agree so it should be No Yes Yes

questions.question_text:
A company has an on-premises application server.
The company wants to use some of the services in Microsoft 365 with the on-premises application server.
You need to choose a cloud deployment model that meets the requirement.
What should you choose?

discussion.content: Yuppers

comments.content: Finally, my favourite, most sensible discussion comment.

discussion.content: 101% is B for sure

Selected Answer: B
Hybrid = On-premise + Cloud
on 4/23/24 exam

Neste cenário, onde a empresa deseja integrar alguns serviços do Microsoft 365 com um servidor de aplicativos local, uma escolha adequada seria um modelo de implantação em nuvem híbrido (opção B). O modelo de nuvem híbrida permite a integração e o compartilhamento de dados e aplicativos entre a infraestrutura local (on-premises) e os serviços em nuvem, proporcionando flexibilidade e escalabilidade. Portanto, a opção correta seria:

B. Híbrido

Selected Answer: B
Usage of both on premises and cloud services is know as Hybrid solution.

Selected Answer: B
‘With’ the app server.

Selected Answer: B
Key words 'to use some of the service' > means both. So answer B: Hybrid
Correct

used by company only -> private for sure
shared with other companies -> public definitely
on-premises server -> hybrid since there is on-prem

Answer is correct
I didn't really get this one for A, it could be using cloud resources in a public cloud, it's very vague

Company A: Private Cloud
Company B: Public Cloud
Company C: Hybird
Some of these questions are pretty obvious if you went through AZ-900 exam

I'm familiar with multiple companies owning a cloud referred
 to as COMMUNITY cloud, which is privately held.
This could also be Public, Public, Private - just used by company only doesn't mean it can't be in the cloud... ugh

Pivate, Public, Hybrid.

However it is also possible:
Private, Private, Hybrid.
